newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico June department store sales rise 3.7 pct.
newsitem.headline: Mexico June department store sales rise 3.7 pct.

text.p: Mexico's department store sales rose 3.7 percent in June compared to the same month a year earlier, the National Association of Self-Service and Department Stores (ANTAD) said on Thursday.
The association also said that supermarket sales fell 0.9 percent in June compared to the same month a year earlier.
For the first six months of the year, department store sales rose 4.8 percent compared to the first half of 1996, ANTAD said.
Supermarket sales for the first half of this year fell 1.3 percent compared to the first half of 1996, the association said.
Supermarket sales need to grow by 22.2 to return to levels from before the December 1994 peso crisis levels, ANTAD said.
Department store sales "appear to be consolidating the start of a recovery," ANTAD said, noting that department stores suffered even more than supermarkets from the crisis.
In June 1995, department store sales fell 37.9 percent compared to June 1994. Department store sales rose by 4.0 percent in June 1996 over June 1995.
ANTAD attributed the June 1997 increase in department store sales to stable inflation in recent months, high-profile discount offers and heightened competition within the sector.
Within department stores, white goods and clothes showed the best growth at 16.8 percent and 4.0 percent, respectively, ANTAD said.
